RMPDescription: Belews Creek Steam Station RMP - Anhydrous Ammonia

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
INTRODUCTION



This RMP has been developed by Belews Creek Steam Station (BCSS), a Duke Energy site, in order to comply with the standards established by the EPA's Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention (40 CFR Part 68). 



PLANT AND PROCESS INFORMATION



BCSS operates an Anhydrous Ammonia (NH3) system as a component supporting the station's Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) of the plant's boiler emissions. NH3 vapor, in the presence of the SCR catalyst, is used to reduce NOx compounds to nitrogen and water, in order to reduce the total NOx effluent emitted from the plant.



The NH3 system is comprised of six storage tanks, with three belonging to U1, and the other three to Unit 2. The station's Maximum Intended Inventory (MII) is < 645,000 gallons or 3,321,750 pounds. The MII includes the storage tanks and piping directly connected to the covered process and the rail cars on site, but, not directly connected to the covered process. This total quantity of NH3 exceeds the EPA's threshold quantity (TQ), which requires the station to comply with their Program 3 regulations. 



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION MEASURES



BCSS is committed to public and employee safety, continued reliable operation, and regulatory compliance. Based on this commitment, the station manager has overall responsibility for the development and implementation of the Risk Management Program. A management system has been developed through the station's Accident Prevention Plan (APP), which clearly defines how this program operates effectively. To ensure that no serious NH3 releases occur, BCSS maintains a release prevention program, which is focused on protecting the public and station employees from the hazards associated with an accident or release. This multifaceted program includes the use of: Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) to evaluate chemical and process hazards and make recommendations for safety improvements; NH3 detection and alarms to rapidly alert oper

ators to any problems; process instrumentation and interlocks, which will shut down the system and isolate NH3 supply to the plant if process conditions (i.e. flow, temperature, and pressure) are not within their appropriate safe operating ranges; written operating procedures to ensure the system is operated consistently and safely; maintenance, inspection, and testing of system components to ensure that they are safe for continuous use; safe work practices to ensure that individuals working on or adjacent to the process are aware of the hazards, can perform their duties safely, and know the actions to be taken in an emergency; incident investigation procedures to investigate accidents and "near-misses" to determine root causes and make needed safety improvements; training on all aspects of the program, operation, maintenance, chemical hazards, emergency response, and related aspects to ensure employees are continuously aware of what is required to operate the system safely; and periodic compliance audits to ensure that the management system and prevention programs are working as they should.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



BCSS hasn't had an accidental release that resulted in injuries or property damage within the past five years. The plant has maintained an excellent safety record throughout its operating history and has never had any major chemical release that may have led to adverse effects on the public.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE



In the event that an NH3 release does occur, BCSS maintains an emergency response program that coordinates with the appropriate Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). BCSS maintains an emergency response team on-site (24/7), with the appropriate number of members, training, and equipment to actively respond to and take action in order to mitigate an NH3 release. Additionally, the station maintains an Emergency Action Plan (EAP), Spill and Release Emergency Response Plan (ERP), and an emergency shutdown procedure to minimize the i

mpacts of a potential release. 



PLANNED CHANGES AND IMPROVEMENTS



BCSS is dedicated to the continuous improvement of the covered process. Further, the station strives to protect the communities we serve and the employees, contractors, and vendors on-site.  The Risk Management Program will be maintained to reduce the risk of accidental releases through training, procedures, equipment maintenance, and safe work practices. Periodically, BCSS will audit the program, review the PHA, coordinate with emergency response organizations, and will update the program as needed to assure safe and efficient control and management of the NH3 system.
